ThermodynamicsÂ¶

The structure of the zero-temperature equation of state in terms of densities comes from the First Law of Thermodynamics:

(1)\[\mathop{d \epsilon} = T \mathop{d s} + \frac{\epsilon + p}{n} \mathop{d n}\]

where \(\epsilon\) is the energy density, \(T\) is the temperature, \(s\) is the entropy, \(p\) is pressure density, \(n\) is number density. We have set the speed of light \(c=1\) such that \(\epsilon\) and \(p\) are in the same units.

We set \(\mathop{d s} = 0\), and we will also use the average mass per baryon \(m_b\) to express in terms of the rest mass density \(\rho\) which also has the units of \(\epsilon\).

(2)\[\mathop{d \epsilon} = \frac{\epsilon + p}{\rho} \mathop{d \rho}\]

This implies a single-parameter equation of state, where we express thermodynamic quantities in terms of a single parameter, for example \(\epsilon(\rho)\) and \(p(\rho)\); in fact, only one of these is required, as we can use the first law to determine one from the other. For example, given \(p(\rho)\), we can use the reformulation [1] of (2) as

(3)\[d\left(\frac{\epsilon}{\rho}\right) = - p d\frac{1}{\rho},\]

along with the surface boundary condition, to determine \(\epsilon(\rho)\).

We will later make use of the specific enthalpy density \(h\),

(4)\[h = \frac{\epsilon + p}{\rho}.\]

One can show [2] for the single-parameter equation of state that:

(5)\[\frac{ dh}{dp} = \frac{h}{\epsilon + p}.\]

Footnotes

[1]Energy density from pressure and rest mass density
[2]Derivative form of enthalpy
